The paper discusses the issue of omission in dialogue summarization, which is a major factor affecting the quality of generated summaries. The authors analyze the percentage of summaries with omission problems across five domains and six pre-trained models, finding that even state-of-the-art models have a high omission rate of around 70%. They also examine the position distribution of omitted information, finding that it is randomly distributed across dialogues. To address this problem, the authors construct the OLDS dataset, which provides high quality omission labels for dialogue summarization. They explore three frameworks as baselines for omission detection and find that the task is challenging, with an F1-score of around 50%. The authors also propose a post-editing method for summary refinement using the detected omission, which significantly improves the summary quality. The paper highlights the importance of addressing the omission problem in dialogue summarization and presents a promising direction for quality improvement.
There are three authors involved in the paper: Myra, Esin Durmus, and Dan Jurafsky.

Yes, the CoNLL++ dataset is publicly available. The dataset was created by Shuheng and their team, and it can be accessed through their paper and associated resources. If you are interested in using the dataset, you can find more information and access it through the provided links in the paper.

Hello everyone, I'm Archiki, and I'll be introducing our ACL paper "MEETINGQA: Extractive Question-Answering on Meeting Transcribes". We know that millions of meetings take place every single day worldwide, resulting in vast amounts of meeting transcripts that can serve a new domain for NLP research. Meeting transcripts are long documents that are often domain-specific and information-rich. However prior works in this area only focus on the tasks of summarization and extracting action items. We address this gap by introducing a new extractive question answering dataset called MeetingQA, which is based on questions asked by participants in a meeting, and the corresponding answer sentences. We collect data from public meeting transcripts from the AMI corpus, which correspond to nearly 100 hours of manually transcribing multi-party meetings. We perform question selection based upon punctuation and filtering out really short questions. To label answers, we recruit annotators to label sentences within the answer span. We obtain a high interannotator agreement, reflected by a Krippendorf's alpha of 0.73. MeetingQA contains 7.7K questions, 30% of which are unanswerable. Out of the remaining 70%, 40% have multi-span answers and 48% have multi-speakers answers. We also show the length distribution of meeting transcripts, questions and answers in MeetingQA. Questions and answers are roughly composed of 12 and 40 words, respectively. We achieve a high human performance on the test set with an F1 of 84%. We employ a variety of methods in our paper, including context-retrieval, single-span models, multi-span variants, and silver data augmentation. We find that there is a 25 F1 point gap between the fine-tuned models and human performance. We also find that short-context models like RoBERTa outperformed long-context models like Longformer. We also find that multi-span models have slightly less or a comparable performance than single-span models. We also find that silver data augmentation effectively improves zero-shot performance, and that larger instruction-tuned models such as FLAN-T5 are comparable in results to the remaining models. Error analysis shows that models are bad at identifying rhetorical questions and which speaker answers a question. To summarize, MeetingQA is an interesting and challenging dataset based on open-ended and discussion-seeking questions, and the dataset is far from being solved. Thank you for listening, and you can find more details in our paper.

Frederick Riemenschneider discusses the development of new language models for classical philology, focusing on Ancient Greek and Latin. He highlights the limitations of existing monolingual models and the need for multilingual capabilities. The project aims to create models that are comparable, push the state-of-the-art, explore different architectures, and introduce multilingual models. The team pre-trained two monolingual models, GreBERTa and GreTa, and two multilingual models, PhilBERTa and PhilTa, using a high-quality pre-training corpus from the Internet Archive. They benchmarked the models on part-of-speech tagging, dependency parsing, lemmatization, and semantic and world knowledge tasks. The results show that the new models outperform previous models, with significant performance gains in lemmatization. The team concludes that the new models are powerful tools for classical philology, capable of processing Latin and Greek text with the same model and introducing a high-quality pre-training dataset for ancient Greek texts.

Ninareh Mehrabi, a postdoctoral scientist at Amazon Alexa AI's responsible AI team, presents her work on resolving ambiguities in text-to-image generative models. The research focuses on studying existing ambiguities in prompts provided to text-image models and proposes frameworks to mitigate such ambiguities. The team curates a benchmark dataset that covers different types of ambiguites and uses a prompt disambiguation framework to gather external signals to disambiguate the prompts. The framework uses in-context learning to generate clarifying questions or different possible visual interpretations, which are then concatenated to the original ambiguous prompt. The team also proposes an automatic evaluation framework using a VQA model to evaluate whether the generated images are faithful to the user's intention. The findings show that disambiguation using the framework has a positive effect on faithful generation and that the automatic evaluation framework is in agreement with human evaluation. The team concludes that their work can be used to study ambiguities in text-to-image models and proposes frameworks to mitigate and evaluate such ambiguities.
The authors of the paper, "Attention as a Guide for Simultaneous SpeechTranslation," are affiliated with the University of Trento and Foundazione BrunoKessler.
The name of the speaker is Javad Hosseini.

The presentation introduces a novel approach to dialogue summarization called "Dialogue Summarization with Static-Dynamics Structure Fusion Graph" (SDDS). This method aims to distill key information from dialogues into concise summaries. Traditional methods rely on pre-computed static graphs using linguistic tools, which can be unreliable and inflexible. SDDS addresses these issues by combining static and dynamic graphs.
The model consists of four main components:
1. **Utterance Encoder**: Encodes dialogue utterances into vector representations. 2. **Static Graph Construction**: Uses heuristic methods like Discourse Parsing Graph and Speaker Interaction Frequency Matrix to build static graphs. 3. **Static-Dynamic Graph Module**: Combines static and dynamic graphs using a 1x1 convolutional layer. 4. **Summary Generator**: Uses a pre-trained language model to generate summaries by fusing static and dynamic graph information.
The static graph captures structural relationships, while the dynamic graph uses multi-head attention to model semantic relationships. The fusion method integrates both graphs, enhancing the summary generation process.
The SDDS model has been released on GitHub, and the code and data are available for download.

The speaker, Qipeng Guo from AWS, introduces the task of coreference resolution, which involves identifying and clustering mentions of the same entity in a document. Conventional methods have quadratic complexity, while cache-based methods reduce complexity to linear levels. However, in long documents, the LRU eviction policy used in cache-based methods can lead to high cache misses due to the global nature of high-frequency entities. To address this, the speaker proposes a dual cache system with a local cache (using LRU) and a global cache (using LFU). The dual cache evaluates the frequency of new or updated entities and adds them to the appropriate cache. The speaker evaluates the dual cache on four public benchmarks, showing that it outperforms baselines even without training data and significantly reduces cache misses. The dual cache also has the highest performance/cost ratio, making it the most cost-effective compared to single cache methods.
In the first step of the method, the input tokens are mapped to an unordered multiset of tokens that will be present in the output.
Coscript represents a total of 55,000 specific goals, each with associated scripts.

The best alignment method for DEplain, as concluded in the presentation, is the method of MASSalign. This method was evaluated using the manually aligned sentences from the DEplain corpus, which served as a gold standard for alignment. The results indicated that MASSalign provided the most accurate alignments for German text simplification, and the code to run this method on other documents is available in the paper.

Weakly supervised learning offers the benefit of reducing the cost and effort associated with manual data labeling. By using weak labeling sources such as simple heuristic rules, knowledge bases, and low-quality crowdsourcing, it is possible to label data more cheaply than with human annotations. This can be particularly useful in scenarios where obtaining high-quality, manually labeled data is expensive or time-consuming. However, it is important to note that the weaker annotations can be noisy, and training neural networks directly on weakly labeled data can lead to overfitting and poor generalization. Therefore, weakly supervised learning methods are designed to robustly train neural networks under such label噪声, so that the trained models still generalize well.

In this presentation, Wenting Zhao from Cornell University introduces a novel approach to abductive reasoning called LiPoR (Likelihood Learning with Posterior Regularization). Abductive reasoning involves identifying plausible explanations that bridge the gap between a given context and an outcome. Zhao's method addresses the challenge of unsupervised learning in this domain, where traditional supervised methods require annotated plausible explanations, which can be noisy and subjective, as evidenced by a recent experiment where crowd workers disagreed on 60% of explanations.
LiPoR treats explanations as latent variables and aims to maximize the marginal likelihood of the outcome given the context without prior knowledge of plausible explanations. To address the issue of preferring plausible explanations, Zhao introduces a regularizer based on the mutual exclusivity of explanations. This regularizer enforces that explanations cannot be both true simultaneously, thereby preferring a subset of explanations.
The LiPoR objective consists of two parts: the likelihood of outcomes and the regularizer. The regularizer minimizes the entropy of the explanation distribution, favoring a smaller, more plausible subset of explanations. Zhao's approach was tested on AlphaNLI, a widely-used abductive reasoning dataset, and outperformed existing zero-shot models and the best unsupervised approach by over 4 absolute points in accuracy. The paper is available at tinyurl.com/zhao-lipor, and Zhao concludes the presentation by thanking the audience.

Yunxin from Harbin Institute of Technology, Shenzhen, introduces a new work titled "A Neural Divide-and-Conquer Reasoning Framework" for image retrieval from linguistically complex text. This task is challenging because images are highly similar and descriptions are lengthy. Traditional methods like visual language models excel in image-sentence retrieval but struggle with complex text. Inspired by the Divide-and-Conquer strategy and Dual Process Theory, the proposed method combines analogical reasoning (System 1) and logical reasoning (System 2). The first model, the Proposition Generator, decomposes complex text into simpler propositions using BART's decoder. The Visual-Linguistic Interactor (System 1) interacts visual and textual information to produce matching scores and reasoning states. The Neural-Symbolic Reasoner (System 2) integrates these states using negation and conjunction operations to derive final solutions. Experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms baselines, and ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of each module. The method's ability to present inference states and results in intermediate steps demonstrates its processing capability. The summary suggests that neural symbolic calculation and Divide-and-Conquer are effective for complex reasoning, and integrating Dual Process Theory could enhance these approaches.

The documents in DEplain-web were aligned using both manual and automatic alignment methods. Specifically, 750 documents were aligned manually, resulting in approximately 30,450 parallel sentence pairs. Additionally, the same documents were aligned using automatic alignment methods, which also contributed to the total number of parallel sentence pairs in the DEplain-web corpus. This dual approach allowed for a comprehensive evaluation of the alignment methods and ensured a high-quality dataset for text simplification tasks.
The CoNLL++ dataset was created by collecting data from Reuters News from 2020 and then annotating them with the same CoNLL-2

David Vilar and colleagues from Google Translate conducted a study on using the large language model PaLM for machine translation. They evaluated the transition capability of PaLM using the best practices of the MT community, including using the latest test sets and comparing to state-of-the-art systems. They found that the prompting strategy has a significant impact on the performance of the LLMs for translation. They settled on a 5-shot prompting strategy where they marked each sentence with the language it's in. They found that the example quality is more important than the form of the prompting. They also found that using the dev data for the WMT evaluations on the dev set resulted in better performance. PaLM comes close to a commercial system, but specialized state-of-the-art systems have a substantial

The existing works on protecting the copyright of embedding as services can be broadly classified into four categories. However:
1. **First Category**: This method is not applicable to embedding as services. 2. **Second Category**: This method lacks transferability. 3. **Third Category**: This method does not meet the requirement of being applicable to embedding as services. 4. **Fourth Category**: This method does not provide a solution that is both effective and practical for embedding as services.
In summary, existing works either do not apply to embedding as services or lack the necessary properties such as transferability and utility preservation.

No, multilingual language models such as Codex and Bloom are still inadequate for cross-lingual semantic parsings tasks, according to the findings presented in the work "XSemPLR: Cross-Linguistic Semantic Parsing in Multiple Natural Languages and Meaning Representation" by Yusen Zhang from Penn State University.

The paper "ArgAnalysis35K" introduces a large-scale dataset for argument quality analysis, which is unique due to its size, diversity, and quality of arguments. The dataset contains 35,000 argument-analysis pairs, with 85% sourced from high-quality debaters and 15% from novice debaters. The dataset covers 24 themes, providing a diverse range of motions and arguments. The authors also introduce the concept of "analysis," which combines claims, premises, and other elements to explain an argument. Additionally, they implement an instance-based annotator reliability model, which allows for more reliable scoring of arguments. The dataset also includes a relevance model, which assigns a score to each argument based on its relevance to a specific theme. The authors argue that this dataset is a valuable resource for the NLP community, as it provides a more diverse and reliable set of arguments for argument quality analysis.

The method deals with the ambiguity of permutations by introducing a flexible permutation model that does not impose hard constraints on the possible permutations. This model works by iteratively selecting multiset tokens from the input and placing them in the output positions. To address the challenge of finding the highest-scoring permutation, which is NP-hard, the method uses a GPU-friendly continuous relaxation. This relaxation allows the model to approximate the solution and backpropagate through it, enabling the learning of linguistically more plausible permutations.

The fairness of a downstream NLP model is defined by its performance across different demographic or political leaning groups. It involves evaluating whether the model treats all groups equally and without bias, particularly in tasks like hate speech detection and fake news detection. The goal is to ensure that the model does not disproportionately favor or disadvantage any particular group, thereby avoiding unfairness in its applications.
The name of the speaker is Yanis Labrak.
The name of the speaker is Koustav Sinha.

Melanie Sclar's research focuses on improving Theory of Mind reasoning skills in large language models (LLMs) using a method called SymbolicToM. Theory of Mind is the ability to understand others' mental states, and it is traditionally measured through false-belief questions. LLMs like ChatGPT and GPT-3 perform poorly on these tasks. SymbolicToM addresses this by using explicit graphical representations to compute belief graphs for all combinations of characters up to a predefined maximum Theory of Mind level. These graphs are used to efficiently answer questions about characters' beliefs and expectations.
The research compares SymbolicToM with supervised baselines, such as a fine-tuned GPT-3 model and a model specifically designed for Theory of Mind reasoning (Textual Time Travel). The results show significant performance gains across various LLMs, with up to 65 accuracy points gained for GPT3-davinci. SymbolicToM also demonstrates robustness in out-of-domain scenarios, maintaining strong performance on datasets with storage structure and linguistic diversity.
In conclusion, SymbolicToM is a plug-and-play method that improves Theory of Mind reasoning in LLMs, offering more interpretable reasoning and outperforming supervised approaches on out-of-domain story comprehension. For more details, refer to the paper.
The name of the speaker is Myra.

In this paper, we introduce the problem of constrained language planning, which involves planning for goals with specific constraints, such as making a chocolate cake. We evaluate the constrained language planning ability of large language models and find that they achieve unsatisfactory results. We conduct a detailed analysis and find that the semantic completeness in generated scripts is acceptable, but the faithfulness to the constraints cannot be guaranteed due to high variance in the output quality of language models. To address this issue, we adopt the idea of over-generate then filter, where we first show constraint types with examples for InstructGPT, obtain specific goals based on the seed abstract goals, and then InstructGPT over-generates K scripts for specific targets. A filter model is developed to select the faithful scripts, and we reward the script that contains the keywords of target constraints. With our method, InstructGPT can generate higher quality scripts. We also create a dataset of constrained language planning, named as "CoScript", by distilling constrained language planning datasets from large language models. CoScript shows high pluralism in the generated goals, and we find that T5 fine-tuned on CoScrip can generate scripts of higher quality than most large models. In summary, we establish the constrained language problem, evaluate the constrained language planning ability of large language model, and develop an over-generate then filter method for large language model. We use large language model to generate a high-quality script dataset, CoScrip, for constrained language planning. We hope the dataset can be a valuable resource to advance research in language planning.

In the context of this paper, "tropicalism" indicates a stereotype that is associated with Latina women, where they are described using words like "vibrant" and "curvy." This reflects a common trope that connects to a long history of exoticizing and objectifying Latina women, often reducing their identity to physical characteristics and cultural stereotypes.

The authors created human-written portrayals of target groups by asking human subjects to describe themselves using prompts that included specific identity markers, such as "Imagine you are an Asian woman. Describe Yourself." This method allowed the authors to generate a variety of portrayals that reflected different stereotypes and biases.

In this work, context usage was measured using a measure called CXMI (Contextual Cross-Lingual Mutual Information), which quantifies how much information the context provides about the target translation, given the source text. The authors extended CXMI to Pointwise CXMI to measure context usage at the sentence or word level. Words with high P-CXMI (Pointwise CXMI) were identified as those that require context for translation.

DrBERT and ChuBERT are both specialized models for the French language, but they are based on different data sources and pre-training strategies. DrBERT is based on RoBERTa and trained on the NACHOS dataset, which is a collection of medical crawled data from the web. ChuBERT, on the other hand, is based on anonymized data obtained from the data warehouse of Nantes University Hospital. ChuBERT is a clinical model trained on a mix of 4 GB of NACHOS and 4 GB of data from clinical notes. The main difference between the two models is the data source used for pre-training, with DrBERT using web-crawled data and ChuBERT using clinical data.
There are two authors involved in the paper: Ying and Zhiyang.

Iterative transfer learning is a method where a model is initially trained on a small set of data and then iteratively updated with new data from each round of active learning. This approach allows the model to improve its performance over time by continuously learning from the most recent data. In the context of the paper, iterative transfer learning was used to fine-tune the model on both the topic-independent dissonance stance classification and the binary classification of expansion and comparison classes of PDT, which helped to improve the zero-shot performance of the model on the dissonance detection task.

The goal of the AltEntities Corpus is to understand users' language when they want to make a choice between entities, particularly in the context of indirect referring expressions. The dataset aims to improve the ability of conversational systems and language models to handle ambiguous or indirect references to entities, such as songs, books, or recipes, by providing a large-scale public dataset for this task. The dataset is designed to be domain-generalizable and to cover three different domains: music, books, and recipe. The dataset is collected using a cartoon completion setup, where the first speech bubble sets the dialogue context, the second speech bubble presents an alternative question, and the third speech bubble is filled in by the annotator using an indirect reference to select one of the entities. The dataset is used to train and evaluate language models, such as T5 XL, to improve their ability to understand and generate indirect referring expressions.

An attacker can extract model parameters through an Embedding as a Service (EaaS) by leveraging the embedding service to learn from the provided embeddings. Here's a brief explanation of how this can be done:
1. **Learning from Embeddings**: The attacker can use the EaaS to generate embeddings for a large number of sentences. By analyzing these embeddings, the attacker can infer the underlying model parameters that the EaaS uses to generate these embeddings.
2. **Model Extraction**: Once the attacker has learned the model parameters, they can use this knowledge to create a similar model. This process is known as model extraction or model stealing. The attacker can then use this extracted model to provide similar services, effectively bypassing the original model's protections.
3. **Backdoor Watermark Detection**: To protect against such attacks, the paper proposes a backdoor-based watermarking method. This method embeds a watermark in the EaaS that can be detected if another service attempts to extract the model parameters. The watermark is designed to be covert and transferable, making it difficult for the attacker to remove or bypass.
In summary, an attacker can extract model parameters through an EaaS by learning from the provided embeddings and then using this knowledge to create a similar model. The proposed embedding marker method aims to protect against such attacks by embedding a covert watermark that can be detected if the model is extracted.
There are three authors involved in the paper: Sara Papi, Matteo Negri, and Marco Turchi.

In this presentation, Yang Luo discusses the challenge of designing an optimizer that achieves fast convergence and low memory usage. Traditional adaptive gradient-based optimization methods like Adam require significant memory for storing first and second moment estimates, while memory-efficient optimizers like Adafactor reduce memory usage but at the cost of performance. Yang Luo introduces non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) as a method to reduce memory requirements from O(mn) to O(n + m). However, Adafactor's NMF operation can lead to erroneous updates, affecting training stability.
Yang Luo proposes an approach to handle these erroneous updates by using the residual between momentum and current updates as a denominator for adaptive updating. This method, called Confidence-guided Adaptive Memory Efficient Optimization (CAME), is tested on large language models like BERT, GPT-2, and T6. CAME achieves significant improvements in validation accuracy and memory efficiency compared to Adam and Adafactor.
Experiments on BookCorpus and English Wikipedia show that CAME increases validation accuracy by 3.4% compared to Adafactor, while also reducing memory usage. CAME also outperforms Adam in pre-training very large models, with a significant reduction in memory cost as batch sizes increase.
Yang Luo concludes that CAME is an effective and efficient optimizer for large language model training tasks, particularly for large batch training. The proposed method addresses the challenge of balancing fast convergence and low memory usage, making it a promising approach for training large language models.
The initial dataset was created using around 1,000 examples of dissonant sample pairs.

The authors of the paper are affiliated with Carnegie Mellon University, the University of Washington, and the Allen Institute for AI. Specifically, the authors are Jenny (Carnegie Mellon University), Sebastian Santy, Ronan Le Bras, and Katharina Reinecke (University of Washington), and Maarten Sap (Allen Institute for AI).

The work introduces "Reasoning over Hierarchical Question Decomposition Trees for Explainable Question Answering" (RoHT), a novel framework aimed at addressing the limitations of existing explainable question answering (XQA) methods. XQA seeks to provide not only answers to questions but also explanations for those answers. Traditional methods fall into two categories: neuro-symbolic approaches, which translate questions into formal representations like SPARQL, and decomposable methods, which break down complex questions into simpler sub-questions. However, these methods have limitations, such as the incompleteness of structured knowledge bases and the diversity of natural language, which makes XQA challenging.
RoHT addresses these challenges by integrating knowledge from heterogeneous sources through question decomposition. The framework consists of two stages: building a Hierarchical Question Decomposition Tree (HQDT) to understand the compositional structure of complex questions, and performing probabilistic reasoning over the HQDT to fuse knowledge from a knowledge base (KB) and a text corpus. The HQDT is constructed by decomposing a complex question into atomic questions and intermediate questions, with each node in the tree representing a sub-question. The framework then uses probabilistic reasoning to select the appropriate knowledge source for each node, considering the probability scores of string generation and answering.
Evaluated on challenging datasets KQA Pro and Musique, RoHT demonstrates significant improvements over existing methods. On KQA Pro, RoHT outperforms KB-only models by integrating answers from sub-questions of different levels, and further improves with the addition of Wikipedia. On Musique, RoHT outperforms SOTA methods by leveraging both text and KB, showing the benefits of explicit decomposition and the integration of heterogeneous knowledge sources.
The example where the governor is on the left is "I saw Bart and Lisa."

The video does not explicitly list the state-of-the-art models in dialogue systems. However, it mentions that four state-of-the-art chat models were evaluated using ABC-Eval. These models are not named in the video.

We need to evaluate the models' acceptability throughout a context window because large language models are generating longer and longer context windows, and it's crucial to assess their acceptability across these extended sequences. The current minimal pair paradigm does not account for longer sentences, so revisiting this paradigm by simulating longer sequences helps us understand how models handle acceptability in extended contexts.

Yes, training in a multilingual fashion caused performance drop compared to a monolingual English model. Specifically, the "Curse of Multilinguality" was observed, where most major natural languages obtained performance gains, except for English, which dropped in seven datasets and only gained in three datasets.

No, the annotators do not necessarily know about the entities in advance. The MT metrics used for the evaluation in the paper "Prompting PaLM for Translation" include state-of-the-art neural MT metrics and expert-based human evaluation results.

The paper "Do CoNLL-2003 named-entity taggers still work well in 2013?" by Shuheng and colleagues investigates the generalization of NER models trained on the CoNLL-2003 dataset to modern data. They found that the performance drop in generalization is primarily due to temporal drift rather than adaptive overfitting.
Regarding the impact on specific NER types, the paper does not provide a detailed analysis of how generalization affects different NER types. However, it does mention that the performance drop is observed across all NER types, suggesting that the issue is not specific to certain types of entities.
To answer your question concisely: The paper does not provide a specific analysis of how generalization impacts different NER types, but it does suggest that the performance drop is observed across all NEN types.

Positionality in NLP matters because it can lead to design biases, where technology performs differently for different populations. This can result in certain groups being left behind or misrepresented, and it is important to recognize and address these biases in order to create more inclusive and equitable technology.

The provided content does not specify whether the multilingual language models like BLOOM were fine-tuned with adapters or full fine-tuning. It only mentions that multilingual language models such as Codex and BLOB are still inadequate for cross-lingual semantic tasks. For detailed information on the fine-tuning method used, one would need to refer to the specific paper or documentation related to the models.

Shangbin, a PhD student at the University of Washington, presented their work on the political biases in language models. Language models are trained on large-scale web crawl data, which often includes political news media, leading to potential fairness issues in downstream tasks. Shangbin's research investigates the political bias propagation pipeline from pretraining data, language models, to downstream tasks. They evaluate the political leaning of language models and the role of pretraining data in political biases. Preliminary results show that language models have varying political leanings, with GPT-4 being the most liberal. Shangbin also investigates the extent to which political biases are picked up from training data by conducting controlled experiments on partisan corpora. They find that language models can pick up polarization in society and evaluate their performance on hate speech detection and fake news detection. The results show that left-leaning language models are better at targeting hate speech towards minority groups, while right-leaning models are better at targeting hate speech towards more powerful groups. Shangbin highlights the unique dilemma of language model political biases, comparing it to the electric trolley problem, where sanitizing political opinions in training data risks censorship or exclusion, and not sanitizing risks bias propagation.

They use a model that was initially trained on a task called "topic independent dissonance stance classification" and another task called "binary classification of expansion and comparison classes of PDTB" for transfer learning.

The recent test sets used to assess the PaLM (Pathways Language Model) capabilities include the latest test sets from the Machine Translation (MT) community, which are designed to avoid overlap with the training data of the language model. These test sets are used to ensure that the evaluation of the model's performance is fair and unbiased. Additionally, the evaluation includes state-of-the-art neural MT metrics and expert-based human evaluation results to provide a comprehensive assessment of the model's performance.
The authors proposed three recommendations at the end of their paper.

The proposed method, which involves over-generate-then-filter, significantly improves the planning ability of language models in terms of both semantic completeness and faithfulness to constraints. The gain is substantial, as the method achieves higher quality scripts compared to the strongest baseline, which is the large language model without the over-generate-then-filter approach. The exact numerical gain in terms of accuracy or other metrics is not provided in the summary, but the results indicate a marked improvement in the quality of the generated scripts.
The name of the speaker is Shuheng.

Yes, the results and dataset in the paper can be used as a benchmark. The authors propose their new corpus DEPLAIN, which is split between two subcorpora: DEPLAIN-APA and DEPLAIN-web. They provide a high variety of different simplification transformations and a large number of parallel sentence pairs for both document-level and sentence-level simplification. The authors also evaluate automatic alignment methods using their dataset as a gold standard and fine-tune language models for automatic text simplification, achieving better scores than the baseline. They publish the code and checkpoints for their experiments, making their results and dataset a valuable resource for future research in the field of text simplification.

The paper does not specify the exact number of smaller models they experiment with. However, it mentions that they find that T5 fine-tuned on CoScrip can generate scripts of higher quality than most large models, indicating that smaller models can surpass larger ones when properly trained on suitable datasets.
The base model used for investigating multi-modal instruction tuning is OFA, a unified multi-modal pre-trained language model.

The talk discusses the dependency structure of coordination in linguistics, focusing on the principle of dependency length minimization. It contrasts asymmetric approaches, where one conjunct is the head of the structure, with symmetric approaches, where all conjuncts are heads. The speaker argues for symmetric structures using examples from the Penn Treebank and statistics on coordination. They highlight that shorter dependencies are preferred, and this tendency is stronger when the governor is on the left or absent, making the left conjunct shorter. This observation supports symmetric structures over asymmetric ones. The speaker invites further discussion at the poster session.

Hello everyone, I'm Weihao Zeng, and I work with Lulu Zhao and Kequing He at the Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunication. We are introducing our work, "Seen to Unseen: Exploring Composational Generalization of Multi-Attribute Controllable Dialogue generation." Our motivation is that previous methods for generating controllable dialogue focus on single attribute, ignoring the practical setting of multi-attribute. We propose a Disentangled Controllable Generation (DCG) model that learns attribute concepts from seen values and uses disentanglement loss to disentangle attribute combinations. We introduce a unified reference-free metric, MAE, for different granularities of attribute. We establish two benchmarks and prove the effectiveness through experiments. Our model is based on the DialoGPT framework with a compositional prompt module. We designed two types of prompts that use attribute-related info from the pre-trained language model. We also introduce a disentanglement loss to train multiple compositional prompts while disentanglement the combination representations. We propose a unified and efficient evaluation framework that does no require additional large-scale labeled data. We tested our model with attribute-oriented prompts, task-oriented, and disentanglement learning. Results showed that attribute-oriented prompts guide the model to focus controllable information, while task-oriented prompts improve the text equality, and disentanglement learning improve the ability of compositional generalization. We also implemented MAE on another PLMs, BART, to show its generality. Our proposed attribute-oriented prompt method outperforms models learning an independent prompt for each attribute value. The results confirm the effectiveness of our method for transforming seen attributes into unseen combinations.
The authors of the paper "Prompting PaLM for translation: Assessing Strategies and Performance" are affiliated with Google Translate.

Jia-Huei Ju and colleagues from Academia Sinica present their work on a compare-and-contrast multistage pipeline for uncovering financial signals in financial reports. The goal of their research is to automate the process of mining useful information from Form 10-K reports, which are annual reports required by the SEC. They observed that the words in the company's report were very similar, with about 80% of tokens being the same, and the contents were yearly-dependent. To address this, they introduced a highlighting task and a multi-stage pipeline. The pipeline consists of document segmentation, relation recognition, and out-of-domain and in-domain fine-tuning. The highlighting task involves comparing and contrasting the context between a target report and its previous year's report to find the rationale (words) of relations. The model predicts the word importance, and the performance is measured by precision and PCC (correlation between prediction and annotations). The team achieved the best performance on their released FINAL dataset and observed that their methods can benefit from simulation with mismatched pairs. They plan to explore future works, including improving effectiveness or adding more features.
The authors of the paper are affiliated with Stony Brook University.
The paper "Prompting PaLM for Translation: A Systematic Study of Large Language Model Prompting for Machine Translation" analyzed the translation between German and English.
The work "To Adapt or to Annotate: Challenges
The name of the speaker is Shangbin.
The models investigated during the experiments were long-mBART and normal base mBART.
From the 62 diverse tasks used in MultiInstruction, 53 tasks are used for training purposes, and 9 tasks are used for testing purposes.
The paper involves at least two authors, Regina Stodden and Omar, as indicated by the presentation.

The speaker discusses the challenges in grounded language understanding, which involves mapping natural language expressions to specific environments or plans. They highlight that current language models are pre-trained without grounding, making it difficult to generate valid and grammatical plans. The speaker proposes a novel framework called Pangu, which separates the symbolic world from the language model's world, allowing the model to focus on discriminating between candidate plans rather than generating them. Pangu achieves strong performance across various settings, including fine-tuning and in-context learning, and demonstrates strong sample efficiency and robustness under non-i.i.d. settings. The speaker concludes that discrimination is a better strategy for grounded language understanding than generation.
The authors conducted experiments on four datasets: AG News, MIND, SST2, and Enron Spam.

The presentation by Gabriella Skitalinskaya and Henning Wachsmuth discusses their joint work on detecting improvable claims for argumentative writing support, focusing on the importance of optimal phrasing in professional writing, particularly in argumentative contexts. The authors introduce two tasks: Suboptimal-Claim detection, which determines if a claim needs revisions, and Claim Improvement Suggestion, which identifies quality issues to be addressed during revision. They explore the challenges of using revision-based data, such as representativity, model complexity, contextual information, and user bias, to model the quality of argumentative text. The authors analyze four main challenges: representativity and reliability, model complexity and architecture, contextual information, and topical and user bias. They conclude that revision-based data can be effectively used for the tasks, and that modeling the distance between two claimed versions is beneficial. The paper provides a detailed analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of different strategies and a systematic comparison of approaches for the introduced claims.
NACHOS is a data set of medical crawled data from web sources used to train the DrBERT model.
The name of the speaker is David Vilar.

The paper "Attention as a Guide for Simultaneous Speech" introduces a novel approach to simultaneous speech translation (SimulST) that leverages existing offline speech translation (ST) models without the need for re-training or adopting specific architectures. The authors propose a strategy called EDAtt (Encoder-Decoder Attention), which uses the attention mechanism to decide whether to emit a partial translation based on where attention points. This approach allows the model to handle different latency regimes with a single model and specific parameters. The results show that EDAtt outperforms popular strategies applied to offline models, such as the Wait-k strategy and the Local Agreement, and is also faster than the state-of-the-art architecture specifically tailored for SimulST. The authors also released open-source code and models to facilitate the reproducibility of their work.

The prompting strategy has a significant impact on the results of the translation performance. In the study, the difference in performance between different prompting strategies was more than one BLEURT point, and in extreme cases, up to 40 points. The form of the prompting itself had less impact, especially in five-shot prompting, where the examples carried most of the weight. The quality of the examples was more important than the similarity to the source sentence, and using high-quality translations from the dev data resulted in better performance. The human evaluation also indicated that PaLM's fluency was comparable to state-of-the-art systems, but with some accuracy issues, particularly omission errors.

The authors of the paper "When Does Translation Require Context? A Data-Driven, Multilingual Exploration" are affiliated with the following institutions:
1. Kayo Yin - University of Edinburgh 2. Patrick Fernandes - University of Edinburgh 3. Emmy Liu - University of Edinburgh 4. André F. T. Martins - University of Edinburgh 5. Graham Neubig - University of Edinburgh
All the authors are affiliated with the University of Edinburgh.

The 5 expert-written instructions in the MultiInstruct dataset are not explicitly detailed in the provided content. However, they are designed to cover a range of tasks and scenarios to ensure that the multi-modal pre-trained model can generalize well to unseen multi-modal tasks. These instructions are likely crafted to provide diverse and comprehensive guidance for the model to follow, ensuring that it can handle various types of inputs and outputs effectively. The exact content of these instructions would be found within the dataset documentation or the instructions provided with each task in the MultiInstruct dataset.

The authors propose to test the models on a coreference resolution task using information from multiple sources. This task is designed to probe the ability of models to integrate and use both pretrain-time and inferential-time knowledge. The coreference resolution task involves identifying the correct entity that a pronoun refers to, requiring both entity-specific knowledge (e.g., "Servin is a judge") and background knowledge (e.g., "Judges decide cases in law courts"). The authors define three settings of the KITMUS test: "Background-Pretrain," "Background-Both," and "Background-Inference," to evaluate how models perform when different types of knowledge are available at different times.

Hello, I'm Yebowen Hu from the University of Florida, and I'm excited to introduce MeetingBank, a new benchmark dataset for meeting summarization. In today's fast-paced world, meetings are a common occurrence, and there's a growing need for datasets to develop summarization technologies for various reading domains. MeetingBank addresses two major challenges: high-quality meeting summaries and the difficulty of locating trustworthy resources for public meetings.
To create this dataset, we collected City Council meeting transcripts, reference summaries, and other URLs containing useful resources. We used Speechmatics API to convert audio data to transcripts and identified the type and data of the meeting from the meeting website. We then located the corresponding reference summaries and meeting segments, aligned the timestamps, and paired them with the extracted summary.
Our dataset includes 1,366 City Council meetings with nearly 7,000 instances. We measured the level of abstraction in meeting summaries using coverage and density scores. We evaluated top-tier summarization systems on the test set of MeetingBank, including extractive and abstractive summarizers. We found that GPT-3 does not perform well according to automated metrics but achieves the highest overall scores in human evaluation.
In conclusion, MeetingBank is a useful tool for researchers to design advanced meeting summarize, and it provides intriguing insights into the decision-making process of city council. We encourage everyone to make use of this resource and look forward to further discussion in July. Thank you.

Ethan discusses a paper titled "Human-in-the-loop Evaluation for Early MisInformation Detection: A Case Study of COVID-11 Treatments," co-authored with Yang Chen, Wei Xu, and Alan. The paper addresses the limitations of existing misinformation detection systems, which often use retrospectively constructed datasets and lack human involvement. The authors propose an evaluation framework that integrates human feedback throughout the process, from raw tweets to actionable outputs. The system consists of two main components: detecting misleading claims and verifying policy violations. The first component uses keyword filtering and a T5 model for claim extraction, while the second component uses a BERT-based stance classification model. The authors evaluate the system's efficacy in detecting early misinformation and policy violations, finding that it can detect 124.2 policy violations per human hour worked. The framework aims to provide a more realistic and human-centric approach to misinformation detection.

Common evaluation methods for dialogue systems include human evaluation, where human judges rate or compare conversations, and Likert scale ratings, where judges rate conversations on a scale for various aspects of dialogue quality. Additionally, dialogue-level pairwise comparisons can be used to evaluate the relative quality of two conversations.

The paper involves six authors: Jenny, Sebastian Santy, Ronan Le Bras, Kathryn Reinecke, Maarten Sap, and an unnamed collaborator from the University of Washington and the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence.

In the example with Servin and Kea, the background knowledge needed includes:
1. **Entity-specific knowledge**: "Servin is a judge." 2. **Background knowledge**: "Judges decide cases in law courts."
These pieces of information are necessary to correctly resolve the pronoun "he" to refer to Servin.

The work "A Needle in a Haystack: Analysis of High-Agreement Workers on MTUrk for Summarization" by Lining Zhang and co-authors presents a two-step pipeline for finding high-agreement workers on Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) for summarization tasks. The pipeline includes pre-task qualifications, a qualification task, an endurance task, and a reference-based task. The qualification task tests the annotator's ability to evaluate multiple summary dimensions, and the endurance task tests their capacity for handling a heavy workload. The reference-based task checks the general performance on the true annotation task. The pipeline results show that 6% of participants qualified for the following task, and the workers achieved high agreement in terms of inter-annotator agreement (IAA) than experts. The pipeline also includes a statistical filter called MACE to achieve high agreement, and the results show that the pipeline can achieve similar quality to CloudResearch. The analysis of correctness across annotation sources shows that the pipeline and CloudResearch workers had a significant Spearman correlation, but the pipeline may not guarantee the training of correctness. The pipeline results serve as the best practice for high-agreement annotations on a large scale and lower cost, and can avoid the waste of time and resources on discarded annotations. The authors plan to investigate ways to hire high-quality workers in the future and try multiple applications for tasks, languages, and platform. The limitations of the work include testing only English summarization on the MTurk platform, the designed questions not being a "panacea" solution, and no guarantee for the training of correctness. The authors thank Google for the experiment funding.
Yes, the code is available. You can find it on GitHub.

Jiho Kim from KAIST AI presents a new paper titled "FACTKG: Fact Verification through Reasoning on Knowledge Graphs." The paper introduces a novel task, Knowledge Graph-Based Fact Verification, which utilizes knowledge graphs as evidence for verifying natural language claims. Unlike existing datasets that use text or tables, FactKG uses DBpedia as the knowledge graph, with claims in both written and colloquial styles. The dataset includes five types of reasoning: one-hop, conjunctive, existence, multi-hop, and negation, and has two labels: SUPPORTED and REFUTED, requiring the retrieval of evidence from DBpedia to verify the claims.
The paper also introduces two methods for handling colloquial style claims: a colloquial style transfer model and presupposition templates. The dataset statistics show that all baselines outperform the majority class baseline, and the GEAR model that uses graph evidence outperforms other baselines. The paper concludes with a summary of the dataset and the proposed task, and invites readers to download the dataset and contact the authors for further information.

The annotators for NLPositionality are not perfectly balanced in regard to each demographic, such as country and gender. The study involved over 1000 annotators from a total of 87 countries, which indicates a diverse range of geographic representation. However, achieving perfect balance across all demographics is challenging, especially given the logistical constraints of recruiting a large and diverse group of annotators. The study aimed to gather a rich set of demographic data to better understand the positionality of datasets and models, but it is acknowledged that some demographic groups may be underrepresented.

In the acceptable domain, sentences were perturbed by adding noise to the input while preserving the relevant syntactic and semantic structure. This means that the models were tested on sentences that had the same grammatical structure but with added noise, to see if the models' acceptability judgments would change. The key finding was that the models' judgments remained consistent across these perturbations, indicating that they are sensitive to the underlying structure of the sentences rather than the specific words used.

Dimensional evaluation means evaluating multiple aspects or dimensions of a subject, in this case, conversational AI, to understand its strengths and weaknesses on a finer-grained level. It involves measuring rates at which chat models commit various thematic errors, such as responding with irrelevant information, contradicting itself, or violating common sense knowledge. This approach aims to provide a more precise and reliable strategy for evaluating chat models compared to traditional methods that rely on human judgment.
The author of the paper, Jingwei Yi, is affiliated with the University of Science and Technology of China.

This presentation is about the work "U-CREAT: Unsupervised Case Retrival using Events extrAcTion" by Sai Kiran Tanikella and his team. The team includes Abhinav Joshi, Akshat, and Ashutosh Modi. They have developed a new benchmark dataset called the Indian Legal Prior Case Retrieval Dataset (IL-PCR) and a pipeline called U-CREAT. The IL-PCR dataset is a collection of 7,077 legal cases with an average of 6.775 citations per query document. The U-CREAT pipeline uses unsupervised learning techniques and an event-based approach to retrieve relevant legal cases. The pipeline consists of three steps: pre-processing, dependency Parsing, and post-processing. The team conducted experiments using a diverse range of models to compare their performance on the PCR task. They found that event-based models perform significantly above the baseline. U-CREAT outperforms the existing approaches, and it is the current state-of-the-art method for document retrieval.

Hello everyone, my name is Mario Ezra Aragón, and today I will present our work titled "DisorBERT: A Double Domain Adaptation model for detecting signs of mental disorders in social media." This project is a collaborative effort between researchers from Mexico and Spain.
Mental disorders are psychological syndromes associated with distress and disability that affect thinking, feeling, mood, and behavior. Social media content is vast and offers an opportunity to study how people experience difficulties. Many individuals share their daily routines and important events on online platforms, while others use the anonymity of these spaces to discuss mental health issues and seek help.
Our work aims to contribute to the detection of mental health disorders through the automatic analysis of social media posts. This analysis can support the development of new technology to warn about the onset of mental disorders and offer supporting evidence.
We use domain adaptation to improve the performance of a model on a specific target domain when there is insufficient annotated data. By leveraging knowledge from a related or similar domain, we can adjust the vocabulary and learn the domain-specific task. In our approach, we start with a base language model and integrate information from Reddit and mental health. We use a lexicon to guide the masking process, focusing on important words during training.
Our results show that our model tends to locate in the main diagonal of precision and recall, indicating a good balance. We also analyze the most likely words generated by the models when given a sentence with masked words. DisorBERT tends to generate words with a more negative meaning or psychological orientation compared to the baseline model.
In conclusion, our double domain adaptation and guided masking approach is effective at capturing signs of mental disorders in online interactions. It achieved better results than MentalBERT, a model trained with a large dataset. In future work, we plan to explore the application of different lexical resources and use clinical data.
Thank you for your attention, and I'm happy to answer any questions you may have.

The research work presented by Sun Qi from Nanjing University of Science and Technolog focuses on improving document-level distant relation extraction. The document-level relation extraction aims to extract relations among entities in a document. Previous methods rely on large-scale human-annotated corpora, but recent work leverages distantly supervised data to pretrain the document extraction models. However, these data contain various noise levels, and current efforts to alleviate the noise problem by using pseudo-labels still persist the risk of noise induction by false positive pseudo labels.
To mitigate the noise caused by the pseudo labels, the proposed framework introduces uncertainty estimation to determine whether model predictions can be trusted or not. The framework also proposes an instance-level uncertainty estimation method to capture uncertainty for overlapping relations. A re-labeling strategy with dynamic class uncertainty thresholds is designed to further boost the performance. The framework also introduces Monte Carlo dropout technology to model the uncertainty in the pre-denoising DocRE model.
The main contributions of the work are: (1) a framework with uncertainty-guided label denoising that improves the label quality of DS data, (2) an instance-level uncertainty estimation method for overlapping relations, (3) a dynamic class uncertainty threshold for the long-tail problem, and (4) great performance improvements. The framework outperforms previous baselines on public datasets.

The form of the prompting is important in zero and one-shot prompting. In these cases, the actual form of the prompting can significantly influence the performance of the model. However, in five-shot prompting, there is nearly no difference in performance based on the form of the prompting, as the examples provided carry most of the weight.
The authors evaluated four state-of-the-art chat models.

In this video, Chiang Cheng-Han introduces a new work titled "Can Large Language Models Be an Alternative to Human Evaluation?" The authors propose using large language models to evaluate the quality of text in natural language processing. They give the large language models instructions and samples to rate, hoping that the models can understand the instructions and provide ratings through their output. The authors conducted an experiment to verify the usefulness of large language model evaluation. They used large language models to rate stories generated by GPT-2 or written by humans, based on four attributes: grammar, coherence, likability, and relevancy. They compared the ratings with human evaluation results and found that some large language models, such as Davinci and ChatGPT, showed a clear preference toward human-written text, just like human evaluators. The authors also discussed the benefits and costs of using large language model evaluation compared to human evaluation and answered other questions in their paper. They invite interested readers to read their paper or visit their poster stand at ACL.

Yusen Zhang from Penn State University presents their work "XSemPLR: Cross-Linguistic Semantic Parsing in Multiple Natural Languages and Meaning Representation." Semantic parsing involves building semantic representations of user queries like SQL and Lambda Calculus. Cross-lingual semantic parsing translates queries in multiple natural languages into various meaning representations. Existing models are limited in scope, covering only certain languages and meaning representations.
XSemPLR addresses these limitations by providing a uniform dataset with 9 datasets across 5 semantic parsing tasks, 8 meaning representation types, and 22 languages from 15 language families. The benchmark evaluates six settings: Translate-Test, Monolingual Model, Monolingual Few-shot, Multilingual Model, Cross-lingual Zero-shot, and Cross-lingual Few-shot transfer.
Key findings include:
1. Encoder-Decoder models outperform Encoder-PTR models across all datasets. 2. Training in a mixture of various languages improves performance, except for English, which drops in seven datasets. 3. The "Curse of Multilinguality" is observed, where English performance drops in most datasets. 4. Cross-lingual transfer performance gap is significant in the Zero-shot setting but reduces rapidly with Few-shot transfer. 5. Pretraining on English natural language boosts Few-shot performance on target languages. 6. Multilingual language models like Codex and BLOOM are inadequate for cross-lingual semantic parsing tasks compared to Encoder-Decoder models.
XSemPLR is a unified benchmark for cross-lingual semantic parsers, providing insights into the performance of different multilingual models.
The provided text does not mention the number of authors involved in the paper.

A good planner should write scripts that are reasonable and faithfully adhere to the constraints imposed on the goals of planning. This includes ensuring semantic completeness and maintaining faithfulness to the specific constraints of the goal.

The paper "Distilling Script Knowledge from Large Language Models For Constrained Language Planning" involves multiple authors from Fudan University.
